name: Ad Hominem
definition: Attacking the person making a claim instead of addressing the claim’s reasons or evidence.
rationaleTips: Separate the claim from the claimant
Flag insults or motives replacing reasons
Ask: would this rebuttal work if a different person said it?

name: Straw Man
definition: Misrepresenting or oversimplifying an opponent’s claim to make it easier to refute.
rationaleTips: Compare original wording to the attacked version
Look for exaggeration or omission of key qualifiers
Restate the strongest version before critiquing

name: False Dichotomy
definition: Presenting two options as the only possibilities when other reasonable alternatives exist.
rationaleTips: Search for hidden third options
Scan for either/or language without justification
Test by adding a plausible alternative

name: Appeal to Authority
definition: Claiming a statement is true because an authority says so, without relevant expertise or supporting evidence.
rationaleTips: Check domain relevance and consensus
Prefer cited evidence over titles
Ask for the underlying reasons or data

name: Genetic Fallacy
definition: Evaluating something based on its origin or source rather than its current merit or validity.
rationaleTips: Judge ideas by current merit, not origin
Bad sources can occasionally be right
Good sources can sometimes be wrong

name: Composition
definition: Assuming that what is true of the parts must be true of the whole.
rationaleTips: Properties of parts don't always apply to wholes
Consider emergent properties
Look for system-level effects

name: Division
definition: Assuming that what is true of the whole must be true of its parts.
rationaleTips: Properties of wholes don't always apply to parts
Consider individual variation
Look for distribution effects

name: Appeal to Ignorance
definition: Claiming something is true because it hasn't been proven false, or false because it hasn't been proven true.
rationaleTips: Lack of evidence isn't evidence of absence
Consider who bears burden of proof
Distinguish between unknown and unknowable

name: Special Pleading
definition: Applying standards, principles, or rules to others while making oneself an exception without justification.
rationaleTips: Look for unjustified exceptions
Check if standards apply consistently
Ask why this case is different

name: Equivocation
definition: Using a word with multiple meanings in different senses within the same argument.
rationaleTips: Track how key terms are used throughout
Define important terms clearly
Watch for subtle meaning shifts

name: Burden of Proof
definition: Shifting the responsibility of providing evidence from the person making a claim to someone else.
rationaleTips: The claimant must provide evidence
You can't prove a negative
Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence

name: Appeal to Pity
definition: Attempting to win an argument by exploiting sympathy or pity rather than using evidence.
rationaleTips: Separate emotional appeals from logical arguments
Pity doesn't determine truth
Consider if sympathy is relevant to the claim

name: False Analogy
definition: Comparing two things that are not sufficiently similar in relevant ways to support the conclusion.
rationaleTips: Check if compared items are truly similar
Look for relevant differences
Consider if the analogy supports the conclusion

name: Slippery Slope
definition: Asserting that a proposal will trigger a chain of worsening outcomes without adequately justified links between steps.
rationaleTips: Demand specific mechanisms for each step
Quantify likelihood instead of assuming inevitability
Watch for vague escalations

name: Bandwagon
definition: Claims are accepted as true because many believe them.
rationaleTips: Popularity ≠ evidence
Check if consensus is based on expertise or mere numbers
Historical examples show majorities can be wrong

name: Red Herring
definition: Introducing irrelevant information to distract from the main argument or issue.
rationaleTips: Ask: does this address the original question?
Identify when topics suddenly shift
Redirect back to the core issue

name: False Cause
definition: Assuming that because two events occurred together, one must have caused the other.
rationaleTips: Look for alternative explanations
Check if correlation implies causation
Consider confounding variables

name: Hasty Generalization
definition: Drawing broad conclusions from insufficient or unrepresentative examples.
rationaleTips: Evaluate sample size and representativeness
Look for cherry-picked examples
Ask: is this pattern truly consistent?

name: Circular Reasoning
definition: Using the conclusion as evidence for itself, creating a logical loop without external support.
rationaleTips: Check if premises depend on the conclusion
Look for restated claims as evidence
Trace the logical chain for loops

name: Tu Quoque
definition: Deflecting criticism by pointing out the accuser's hypocrisy instead of addressing the argument.
rationaleTips: Hypocrisy doesn't invalidate the argument
Address the claim, not the claimant's consistency
Two wrongs don't make a right

name: Appeal to Emotion
definition: Using emotional manipulation instead of logical reasoning to persuade or convince.
rationaleTips: Separate emotional content from logical content
Ask: what evidence supports this beyond feelings?
Consider if emotions are relevant to the truth

name: Loaded Question
definition: Asking a question that contains controversial or unjustified assumptions.
rationaleTips: Identify hidden assumptions in the question
Challenge the premise before answering
Rephrase to remove bias

name: Appeal to Nature
definition: Arguing that something is good or correct because it is natural, or bad because it is unnatural.
rationaleTips: Natural doesn't always mean beneficial
Consider that many natural things are harmful
Evaluate based on evidence, not origin

name: No True Scotsman
definition: Dismissing counterexamples by redefining terms to exclude them after the fact.
rationaleTips: Watch for post-hoc redefinitions
Check if criteria keep changing
Hold definitions consistent throughout argument

name: Guilt by Association
definition: Rejecting an argument because of negative associations with the person or group presenting it.
rationaleTips: Judge arguments on merit, not associations
Separate ideas from their proponents
Consider if the connection is actually relevant

name: Middle Ground
definition: Assuming that the truth must lie somewhere between two extreme positions.
rationaleTips: The middle isn't always correct
Some positions may be objectively better
Evaluate each position independently

name: Confirmation Bias
definition: Seeking, interpreting, or recalling information in ways that confirm pre-existing beliefs.
rationaleTips: Actively seek disconfirming evidence
Consider alternative interpretations
Question information that perfectly fits your beliefs

name: Texas Sharpshooter
definition: Cherry-picking data clusters to suit an argument while ignoring the broader pattern.
rationaleTips: Look at the complete dataset
Check if patterns were predicted beforehand
Beware of retrofitted explanations

name: Appeal to Consequences
definition: Arguing that a statement must be true or false based on the desirability of its consequences.
rationaleTips: Truth is independent of consequences
Distinguish between what we want and what is
Evaluate evidence, not outcomes
